description:
I am a resident of the Fort Hill community (Juniper St)  and have discovered that my tap water has been putting out what appears to be contaminated water. I noticed yesterday that the tap water placed in a pitcher had unusual bubbles that remained after the water had settled and floating sediments of some kind. Thinking it was just a fluke I refilled the pitcher after running my cold water again for a while and noticed the same thing again. 
I have already reached out to my immediate  neighbors on Juniper, Thornton and Rockledge Street finding one who also said they were seeing the same thing too. The others haven't responded back as of yet.
issue with their tap water.
I also placed a call today to the Water and Sewer department, their response to my concerns was that the cold weather can cause the unusual bubbles and sediment. My response back was that we have had worse weather in the past with no such affects to our water. 
So I'm not sure what is really happening but my concerns are still there.
 Hopefully it's nothing but we can never be to careful these days. 

Your neighbor
address: Intersection Of Cedar Sq & Juniper St, Roxbury

status_notes: Case Noted. The Boston Parks Department needs specific locations as to where a tree is requested to be planted. For the Boston Parks Department to inspect and plant trees on an entire street we need a petition from the residents that live in front of these locations with the specific addresses before we can inspect the sites for planting. Also, a resident can call the Park Line at 617-635-7275 requesting individual new trees be planted in front of their home. If you have any questions please call the Park Line. Before creating a petition please read the tree planting specifications that the City of Boston has to follow to be able to plant a new tree. https://www.boston.gov/departments/parks-and-recreation/how-get-tree-planted-city-land. If you have questions please call 617-635-7275. Thank you.

description:
I nearly hit a parking enforcement officer today. It freaked me out. No, I wasn't texting or distracted, the officer stepped out into traffic without looking. She was wearing a black jacket and in the cloud/dusk was difficult to see. 

If their job requires them to step into traffic or work in the road, perhaps you could equip each with a reflective vest? They're actually required for all roads that were built with federal funds (all in Boston). 

I really hope no officers get hurt, and certainly am glad they didn't today. Why not invest in safety not stealth?

Thanks!

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) looked into your complaints and determined the following:. The work in questions is National Grid repairing a Grade 2 gas leak. A permit was issued by the Public Works Department to perform the repair work. Construction work on residential streets in Boston is permitted to start at 7:00am. This is the standard starting time for construction work throughout Massachusetts. The times of work are determined by the Boston Transportation Department. If you have any issues with the times set you can call back the Mayors Hotline and they will transfer your case to BTD. The 100' is letting residents know that you cannot park within that 100". The 100" is how much room National Grid will need to maneuver their equipment and perform the work safely and properly. I did speak to National Grid regarding the posting dates, and they acknowledged that they should have been more accurate on the dates that they posted. In this case they are not working weekends and they should have only posted for the 24th and if they do not finish the job today, they would re post the 27th to complete the job. This would have made it clear that there was parking on the weekends. Hopefully the work can be done today. National Grid will  speak to their crews to make sure that they are positing no parking signs as accurately as possible when working in Boston. The City apologizes for the inconvenience of this necessary work. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
description:

This sign is all over this block of the street and it's completely unreasonable for residents where it's already very difficult to find parking! Why wouldn't it be limited to 9-5 and weekdays when most residents wouldn't even notice or be inconvenienced? Makes zero sense. Please amend!!!

status_notes: Case Resolved. . Dear Constituent,. National Grid is installing a new main on your street. The city highly encourages this type of work. It will eliminate possible future emergency leak repairs. The city acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents,. However in the long run the construction is well worth it. The new gas main permit is valid.  The work is expected to be completed sometime in May. Depending on the scope of work, part of or all of the street, may be posted at one time. To ensure as much parking as possible during construction we have instructed the contractor to only post the sections of the street that they will be working within the next week. This is why you see the contractors changing the signs.  If the work becomes more complicated than thought, they extended the no parking date. Or they move the signs down the street as the work progresses. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. status_notes: Case Resolved. Back-up beepers or an observer are required by OSHA for vehicles with an obstructed view to the rear and no one on the ground to help guide the driver. Alarms are typically loud because manufacturers do not know the ambient noise level where the machines will be used. The relevant OSHA regulation is 29 CFR Part 1926.601(b)(4) which requires "a reverse signal alarm audible above surrounding noise level", but only when the motor vehicle has "an obstructed view to the rear". The determination of the noise level is left to the employer. However, because equipment is moved from place to place, the loudest alarms are often selected.
description: Seven hours' worth of reverse-beep tone. Bad for work. Bad for environment. Bad for ears. London banned these tones a decade ago. Could Boston do the same and, as a result, step into the 21st Century?

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for contacting the Boston Transportation Department. We have taken a look at this intersection and found that it does not meet the warrants for stop sign installation. This is due to the fact that Norwell is a one way away from the intersection on one side and an access driveway on the other side. There are no potential vehicle-vehicle conflicts that a stop sign would assist in preventing. Please know that federal criteria in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD) prevents cities and towns from installing stop signs for speed control (Section 2B.04). Stop signs installed for speed control in the past have been found to be counterproductive, and have increased mid-block speeds between stop signs and reduced compliance at stop signs.
description: The intersection of Wheatland and Norwell is very busy. It would be much safer to have a stop sign here. Pls advise when and how one could be installed.
